p: One study evaluated the hypocholesterolemic and hypotriglyceridemic activities of four M. vulgare herb extracts (petroleum ether, chloroform, ethyl acetate, and methanol) using Triton WR-1339-induced hyperlipidemia in mice. Extracts were applied using 0.1 and 0.25 LD 50 concentrations. After 7 h and 24 h of treatment, the intragastric administration of all extracts caused a significant decrease of plasma total cholesterol; LDL cholesterol and triglyceride levels were also significantly lowered by all extracts. Additionally, more polar extracts (methanol and ethyl acetate) showed a significant ameliorative action on elevated atherogenic index (AI) and LDL/HDL-C ratios [ 95]. These findings coincide with recorded decreases in the total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol levels during antidiabetic studies, which was probably due to a stimulation of the insulin secretion [ 86].
